item.title: 8 Things That Dragon Age: The Veilguard Does Better Than Other BioWare Games
item.description:
Key Takeaways

  • Veilguard offers new gameplay mechanics and balancing action with narrative, showcasing BioWare's boldness.
  • Character creator allows for intricate customization and seamless blending of Rooks into scenes.
  • Combat evolves to a more action-oriented style, providing engaging gameplay; smaller maps enhance exploration experience.

BioWare has returned to the Dragon Age universe with Dragon Age: The Veilguard , a release that promises to innovate and challenge expectations. Although the title has divided opinions among fans, it introduces new mechanics that enhance the gaming experience, highlighting the developer's boldness in exploring new elements.

The innovations in The Veilguard offer improvements that many consider superior to previous BioWare titles. The game delves into concepts that captivate the audience, seeking to maintain a balance between action and narrative. With this, the studio presents a Dragon Age that differentiates itself and stands out, even amid discussions in the gaming community.

8 Character Creator

Bioware Gave Players Excellent Character Customization

One of the best features in Dragon Age: The Veilguard is the character creator, allowing players to craft a wide variety of unique Rooks with extensive options to customize even the smallest details. Inspired by The Sims , this tool stands out as one of the game’s greatest strengths, offering something entirely fresh compared to BioWare’s previous titles.

Another highlight is that once a character is created, Rooks seamlessly blend into scenes, fitting naturally into environments and interacting smoothly with other NPCs during dialogue. The character creator encourages creativity, enabling players to personalize their appearance with intricate details. It's an incredible tool for those who love to craft distinct protagonists.

7 Action Combat Feels Incredible

It's Not Like The First One, But Still Good

The first Dragon Age: Origins introduced a more tactical style of combat where players could pause battles and control the entire party, directing each companion individually, much like other beloved CRPGs. However, Veilguard shifts the combat in a more action-oriented direction, with Rook as the only controllable character.

Although it departs from traditional CRPG mechanics, the action combat in this fourth installment feels satisfying and, if refined further in future BioWare titles, could become even more engaging. While this style may not be a perfect match for every medieval setting, franchises like Mass Effect could greatly benefit from these new gameplay mechanics.

6 Amazing Graphics

One Of Bioware's Best Artistic Directions So Far

Although Dragon Age: The Veilguard has more stylized graphics than other BioWare games, the developers nailed it and gave players a beautiful and sometimes colorful title. Even though this change might not please all fans of the franchise, the application of the artistic direction was well executed.

As they travel between the Fade and different regions of the Dragon Age world, trying to save it from demons, players are treated to various incredible and well-detailed scenarios. It is one of the most beautiful games ever created by BioWare, considering the time when each of the developer's titles was released.

5 Smaller Maps Are A Good Thing

Increases Tension During Gameplay

Great maps and open-world games can be amazing when filled with content for players to explore. But sometimes, these vast environments can lack engagement if there’s little to do. Dragon Age: The Veilguard avoids this by not relying on a giant map, instead opting for smaller, mission-based areas to explore.

Fortunately, this approach works in the game’s favor, as smaller maps give developers more opportunities to make every corner unique, filled with items, enemies, or other content to discover. Additionally, dungeon exploration feels less tiresome, creating a more enjoyable gameplay loop throughout the game’s length.

4 Decisions Are Even More Important

Players Are Confronted With Choices That Don't Have Good Outcomes

One of the best aspects of BioWare’s games is how certain decisions made throughout the story can drastically impact events, sometimes even altering the ending. Dragon Age: The Veilguard takes this to a new level. Rook faces pivotal choices during key moments in the plot, intensifying the player's influence on the story.

Most of the time, these decisions don’t offer a perfect solution with a favorable outcome for everyone. Players are often forced to prioritize one aspect at the expense of another, leading to consequences. This narrative approach perfectly aligns with the game’s setting, where the world is on the brink of ruin, and the best anyone can do is to minimize losses rather than save everything.

3 Great Character Designs

Most Have A Striking Presence

The artistic direction the developers chose for Dragon Age: The Veilguard , with more stylized graphics, also served to create some incredible character designs. The companions and other NPCs returning from past games received some alterations that made them even more appealing, such as Isabela, Morrigan, and Varric.

The new characters introduced into the story, especially those who join as Rook's companions during his journey against the elven gods, also have unique visuals aligned with each one's concept. Although this has always been a strong point for BioWare, in this fourth game of the franchise, the developer has further enhanced this aspect.

2 The Game's Companions Have Great Prominence

All Are Unique And Incredible

BioWare has some strong points that it tries to develop and evolve in all its games, such as well-crafted characters and settings. However, in Dragon Age: The Veilguard , these concepts are even greater than in any other game released by the developer so far, delivering an incredible result for players.

Here, all characters have a moment to shine and develop in the story, whether through side missions or even in dialogue. BioWare managed to capture the importance of each one to the plot. Not that this was neglected in other games by the developer, but here they give equal importance to everyone.

1 A Story For Both Veterans And Newcomers

Possible To Be Hooked In Different Ways

Direct game sequels have the problem of engaging much more with long-time players, who have a connection with the world and characters, than with newcomers to the franchise. However, The Veilguard manages to do this in different ways, offering methods for both types of players to become interested in the plot.

The script is interesting and, despite having connections with previous games, it is not as complex as in other titles. This is good for those who do not have in-depth knowledge of the franchise. However, for veterans, BioWare included many old characters, which works to give greater emotional weight in different scenes of the narrative, enhancing the experience.

item.title: Dress To Impress: How To Stop Posing
item.description:
Poses add glamor to your outfit during the fashion showdown in Roblox’s Dress To Impress . You can use simple emotes like Chic and Pose 23 to dramatic ones like Cowboy, Magica, and 360 Swing. And for fans teaming up with partners, there are cool duo options, too, like the Heart Pose Duo and Kawaii Pose Duo.

While it’s easy to use poses in the game, stopping them can get confusing for some. Fans may need to unequip the emote multiple times during the round to keep playing smoothly. Check out this guide to learn how to stop posing in Dress To Impress .

How To Stop Posing In Dress To Impress

There are two simple ways to stop posing in DTI . One method is to re-select your currently equipped pose from the pose section. To do this, tap on the ‘ Dancing Mannequin’ icon located on the right side of the screen, scroll down to the pose you’re using, and re-click once . This will instantly stop the emote.

If your selected pose is far down the list, or you can’t remember where it is, there’s another method you can try. Just tap on any random pose in the pose section and re-click on it to remove it . After that, your avatar will return to its normal posture. DTI fans can even add some poses to a favorite list by hitting the star icon next to them, so they won’t have to navigate down to unselect the best emotes.

How To Get Pose Packs In Dress To Impress

Roblox: Dress To Impress has tons of free poses for players to use. However, fans looking to try out special emotes can unlock exclusive pose packs from the game shop. Before the 2024 Halloween Update, there were only 13 pose packs available, but now players can grab five more unique ones.

These packs can be purchased with in-game currency from the game shop. To buy a pack, click on the ‘Pink Lipstick and White Heel’ icon found on the left side of the screen, then tap on the fourth option with the Film Roll icon, and scroll through the given pose packs . Once you choose a pack, tap on the 'Purchase' button and confirm it next. DTI fans can also preview the pose pack before buying it via the 'Preview' button in the same section.

Here’s the full list of all the paid pose packs in DTI , along with their prices and the number of emotes included:

item.title: Marvel Rivals Could Finally Be the Game for One X-Men Character to Shine
item.description:
Marvel Rivals may essentially be Overwatch with a thick coat of Marvel paint, but it’s tough to deny how special and considered each character’s implementation is thus far. Marvel Rivals might’ve been able to skim each character for whatever superficial and sensational ability they most predominantly wield, and yet it has proven to assess minute details and embed them in each respective character’s playstyle regardless of how suboptimal it would seem in the realm of a 6v6 hero shooter (such as Spider-Man’s spider-sense or wall-crawling).

This would suggest that all future Marvel characters added to Marvel Rivals ’ roster will receive the same treatment and be thorough in their representation, which may be harder to actually execute for some characters more than others. For example, Cyclops is fairly static as a character on paper and, despite not being officially announced as of yet, could be tricky to adapt to Marvel Rivals ’ landscape. That said, the same could’ve been said about roster characters such as Hulk, Groot, or Rocket Raccoon, and Marvel Rivals ’ attention to detail continues to prove that Cyclops could be a welcome addition in the future.

Why Cyclops Joining Marvel Rivals Should Be a No-Brainer

Cyclops’ psionic optic blasts are tremendously powerful, to be clear, but in general these red visor beams arguably aren’t as entertaining to behold as Spider-Man’s web-slinging, Iron Man’s repulsor-blasting, or even Captain America’s shield-ricocheting.

However, in a 6v6 hero shooter like Marvel Rivals that revolves largely around ability-based action and long-ranging projectiles, Cyclops could actually be a key figure. Cyclops could presumably keep opponents at a distance with sweeping optic blasts, perhaps with several modulations such as quick bursts fired as his primary attack or a massive beam ability with a lot of recovery frames.

Mobility is also a pillar of Marvel Rivals ’ gameplay, and it’d be interesting to see if Cyclops’ optic blasts could be utilized to enable midair maneuverability. Marvel Rivals ’ hero shooter encompasses a lot for each character but their move sets aren’t as varied or expansive as a regular action game, which is why Cyclops might be superb with only a handful of attacks and abilities that he’d need in his arsenal.

Furthermore, this is a big reason why Cyclops is fantastic in simpler beat-’em-up games such as the Marvel Ultimate Alliance series or X-Men Legends as he doesn’t need to stretch thinly to meet the demands of a larger suite of mechanics that wouldn’t adequately represent the character. Marvel Rivals ’ current choices for default roster X-Men characters are surprisingly diverse, though, and therefore it might be a while before it eventually reaches Cyclops on a laundry list of possible additions.

Cyclops’ Adaptation Wouldn’t Need to Look Much Further Than Marvel Rivals’ Captain America

Captain America’s Freedom Charge Ultimate could be something of an inspiration for Cyclops’ own as Scott Summers is his own team’s leader and would be expected to have some sort of support ability as well. Freedom Charge grants Captain America and teammates “continuous Bonus Health and Movement Boosts” in the path he carves forward, and it wouldn’t be out of the realm of possibility for Cyclops to imbue himself and allies with a similar buff somehow.

By tapping into support tactics, Cyclops could easily charge forth like Captain America and rally his teammates while possibly having more projectile-oriented versatility than Steve Rogers, whose shield-throwing is intrinsically tied to a specific ability as well as consecutive melee hits. Either way, while Cyclops may not be a singularly phenomenal character when placed next to someone like Magik, Storm, or Scarlet Witch, it seems like it’ll only be a matter of time before Scott—who only recently earned praise and popularity via X-Men ’97 —receives a worthy adaptation.

item.title: Pokemon TCG Pocket Leak Teases Future Events and Content
item.description:
Key Takeaways

  • Four new Pokemon TCG Pocket cards and events are coming, according to a recent leak.
  • Upcoming events include Black Friday sales and a Wonder Pick with Arcanine. Magikarp, Gyrados, and Venusaur events are also coming.
  • The events will run during November and December, assuming the leaks prove true.

A new Pokemon Trading Card Game Pocket leak teases the addition of new events and content. Players have reacted to the launch of Pokemon TCG Pocket with a lot of positivity, which has helped the deNA-developed game reach impressive milestones quickly.

For those who don't know, Pokemon TCG Pocket reproduces the experience of physical Pokemon cards in digital format. To obtain the cards, players open boosters, take part in the Wonder Pick, craft them, or join in events. But although the community has been excited by the game's proposal, some feel that the experience of playing Pokemon TCG Pocket is a bit “barebones” at the moment. Now, new information recently shared brings good news for players in this regard.

Two leaks suggest that four new Pokemon TCG Pocket cards and events are coming to the game. Revealed by Twitter user PokeGirlLauren, a mini set known as “A1a” will be released on December 16, although it is unknown how many cards it will have. The second set will arrive on January 29, 2025, and according to her, will have around 230 new cards that promise to "change the meta completely.” She added that four sets and four mini-sets are expected to be released each year, but did not give any further details such as dates or their contents.

Pokemon TCG Pocket to Receive New Events and Cards Soon

In another Tweet, she also shared the dates of the next Pokemon TCG Pocket events. According to her, there will be a Black Friday event from November 22 to December 2, potentially selling gold at more affordable prices. Two new events, one featuring Magikarp and Gyarados cards, and the other featuring Arcanine, will run from November 22 to 28. The Venusaur promotional card event will run from November 29 to December 13. She also notes that the Arcanine event will be a Wonder Pick in which the EX variant will be available along with holographic cards such as Ninetails, Moltres, and Charizard.

Leaks always have a chance of changing, but if they are confirmed, Pokemon TCG Pocket players will have lots to look forward to, especially Arcanine's Wonder Pick. But while the community waits for an official announcement or new information, there are a variety of events going on in the game currently. The Wonder Pick with Chansey and Meowth promo cards ends on November 15, while the Lapras EX PvE event will end on November 18. For more competitive players, there is also the Genetic Apex PvP event, which will end on November 28.

item.title: [REDACTED]’s Rival Race is the Perfect Jolt of Roguelike Urgency
item.description:
At first glance, [REDACTED] doesn’t necessarily do anything out of the ordinary or outlandish when it comes to how its isometric roguelike gameplay is structured. There are different combinations of weapons, gear, and stats to consider in [REDACTED] , for instance, as well as different resources and currencies players can spend toward permanent upgrades and buffs for subsequent runs.

Perishing is less of a punishment and more of a means of natural progression, and new interactions and opportunities become available as players respawn and carry on into a new attempt to flee from Black Iron Prison in the last escape pod. That said, it’s in this attempt to flee that [REDACTED] becomes remarkably interesting.

[REDACTED]’s Runs Quickly Become a Race Against Colorful Boss Rivals

It would be one thing if [REDACTED] tasked players with simply trekking through The Callisto Protocol ’s Black Iron Prison with the herculean task of carving through countless biophages and automaton sentries. Instead, what’s maybe most unique about [REDACTED] ’s spin on the trendy roguelikes genre is how players are constantly racing to reach the escape pod before other characters can reach it themselves.

[REDACTED] features several bosses that players must slay before they can traverse to a new biome—as well as their own hostile corpse—but intermittently they also have a great chance of running into ‘rivals.’ Rivals are [REDACTED] ’s chief source of dialogue and provide comic relief alongside grueling boss challenges. If this was all they contributed to [REDACTED] , though, it wouldn’t be all that impressive or novel; rather, players track, pursue, and actively sabotage rivals while they themselves are hurriedly trying to rush through rooms and gain a lead.

Once rivals are introduced, a bar as long as players’ screens will appear at the bottom of the HUD where they can monitor how far along rivals are in relation to them, not to mention how close they are to a biome boss. This alone makes clearing rooms faster a massive incentive as players doggedly making their way through rooms will notice rivals taking swift leads and far out-pacing them, which can be devastating early on.

[REDACTED]’s Sabotage Mechanic is a Rush of Adrenaline

[REDACTED] ’s rivals make comments when they’ve passed each other, and the quicker that players clear a room the more they’ll charge a meter allowing them to press one of multiple input combinations to impede or disrupt a rival of their choosing. Inputting these combinations brings a menu up on the side of the screen but does not pause the game, meaning that players must wait for an opportune moment where they won’t be interrupted by a biophage’s attacks nor lose focus anyhow and input a combination incorrectly.

Incorrect inputs fail the sabotage mechanic and players have to then wait for the meter to recharge again, and it can also be quite difficult to actually remember to attack or sabotage a rival when the meter is charged and ready with how speedy players are encouraged to be.

Actually catching up to a rival and going toe-to-toe with them before exit doors activate is less intimidating than the ordinary moment-to-moment pursuit as a result, and with three random rivals racing players in each run there is quite a lot to consider regarding whom players might want to catch up to first and potentially tackle, much less which rivals they’d be fine with securing an early lead to be able to surpass or circumvent in later biomes. There are a ton of mind games [REDACTED] presents with its race premise and how players engage with its sabotage mechanic, and that’s all before players even make a successful escape from Black Iron Prison for the first time.
